column1: El Dorado Hills (EDH) is an unincorporated census-designated place (CDP) in El Dorado County
column3: 22 miles (35 km) east of the state capital of Sacramento. The population was 42
column6: 016 at the 2000 census. This growth is a combination of population increase within the 2000 CDP boundaries and expansion of the boundaries. The area of EDH was expanded from 17.9 square miles (46 km2) in 2000 to 48.606 square miles (125.89 km2) in 2010.El Dorado Hills residents and businesses are most closely affiliated with El Dorado County
column7: a generally rural area. El Dorado County is part of the Sacramento Metropolitan Area because it is socially and economically integrated with the much larger Sacramento County and especially the city of Folsom. El Dorado Hills is recognized nationally for its high median household income
column8: ranking 77th in CNN Money Magazine's best places to live in 2007
column9: with the median household income for 2007 over $115

column1: El Dorado Hills is about 18.6 miles from the 1848 gold find site in Coloma
column2: the impetus for the California Gold Rush. Gold was washed down the South Fork of the American River
column3: into areas now in El Dorado Hills and Folsom
column4: but farming and ranching supplanted the Gold Rush. Portions of two Pony Express routes in this area from 1860-1861 remain as modern El Dorado Hills roads. El Dorado Hills includes the longest surviving section of the Lincoln Highway
column5: the first U.S. transcontinental highway. This section
column7: passes through historic Clarksville and is the predecessor of the modern US 50 route.

column1: The modern history of El Dorado Hills dates back to the early 1960s when original developer Alan Lindsey began its development as a master-planned community. The original master plan
column3: covered the area generally north of U.S. Highway 50
column4: and part of the area south of US 50 now considered to be part of the community. El Dorado Hills was envisioned as a large-scale master-planned community that would be completely planned from its inception as a group of residential "villages". Other land uses in the master plan included a business park
column9: and small commercial centers in each village. The master plan emphasized open space between villages and the opportunity for outdoor recreation.

column2: growth occurred at a moderate pace as new families relocated from Sacramento
column3: Southern California and the Bay Area. This growth consisted primarily of residential housing
column4: as retail developments were limited to two shopping centers on the corners Green Valley & Francisco and El Dorado Hills Boulevard & US 50. Each neighborhood created during this time period was given a name and referred to as a "village" by local inhabitants. The original villages of El Dorado Hills include Ridgeview
column9: the major part of Lake Hills Estates north of Green Valley Road was reorganized into Lake Forest Village
column14: Marina Woods and Windsor Point. Additional villages that have developed subsequently include Fairchild
column21: Laural Oaks and the master-planned community of Serrano.

column1: The 1990 census reported El Dorado Hills's population at 6

column3: but resumed at a staggering pace by the mid-1990s. Businesses

column8: one of the largest master-planned communities in Northern California. Serrano was the site of an innovative case of recycled water irrigation on a large scale.Around 2000
column9: its population growth and commercial development greatly accelerated. Development began in its Town Center Zone to form a true downtown business area
column10: and its Business Park experienced increasing rates of construction and occupancy.

column1: US 50 is the major east–west highway running through El Dorado Hills. The portion of EDH north of US 50 is mainly residential. The portion south of US 50 includes the 885-acre El Dorado Hills Business Park and the Town Center Commercial area
